sen.j: 一条 美賀子（いちじょう みかこ、徳川 美賀子、天保6年（1835年）- 明治27年（1894年）7月9日）は、幕末 - 明治時代の公家女性、徳川慶喜・正室。
sen.e: Mikako ICHIJO (Mikako TOKUGAWA, from 1835 to July 9, 1894) was a court noble woman during the time from the end of Edo period to the Meiji period as well as the lawful wife of Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA.
Mikako ICHIJO (Mikako TOKUGAWA, from 1835 to July 9, 1894) was a court noble woman during the time from the end of Edo period to the Meiji period as well as the lawful wife of Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA.
Mikako ICHIJO (Mikako TOKUGAWA, from 1835 to July 9, 1894) was a court noble woman during the time from the end of Edo period to the Meiji period as well as the lawful wife of Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 実父は今出川公久、養父は一条忠香。
sen.e: Her natural father was Kinhisa IMADEGAWA, and her adopted father was Tadaka ICHIJO.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Her natural father was Kinhisa IMADEGAWA, and her adopted father was Tadaka ICHIJO.
Her natural father was Kinhisa IMADEGAWA, and her adopted father was Tadaka ICHIJO.

sen.j: 昭憲皇太后は義妹。
sen.e: Empress Dowager Shoken was her sister-in-law.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Empress Dowager Shoken was her sister-in-law.
Empress Dowager Shoken was her sister-in-law.

sen.j: 幼名は「延君」（のぶきみ）、当初の諱は「省子」。
sen.e: Her childhood name was Nobukimi and her initial imina (personal name) was Shoko.
Her childhood name was Nobukimi and her initial imina (personal name) was Shoko.
Her childhood name was Nobukimi and her initial imina (personal name) was Shoko.

sen.j: 略歴
sen.e: Brief Personal History
Brief Personal History
Brief Personal History

sen.j: 当初、徳川慶喜は関白一条忠香の娘・千代君（照姫）と婚約していたが、婚儀直前に千代君は天然痘に罹患。
sen.e: At first, Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA got engaged to Chiyogimi (Teruhime), the daughter of Kanpaku (Chancellor) Tadaka ICHIJO, but she was affected with smallpox just before the wedding.
At first, Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA got engaged to Chiyogimi (Teruhime), a daughter of Kanpaku (Chancellor) Tadaka ICHIJO, but she was affected with smallpox just before the wedding.
sen.cmt: 「娘」は一人とは限らないのでtheではなくaとします。
sen.e: At first, Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA got engaged to Chiyogimi (Teruhime), a daughter of Kanpaku (Chancellor) Tadaka ICHIJO, but she was affected with smallpox just before the wedding.

sen.j: そのため代役として立てられたのが延君であった。
sen.e: Therefore, Nobukimi was chosen as a replacement.
Therefore, Nobukimi was chosen as a replacement.
Therefore, Nobukimi was chosen as a replacement.

sen.j: 延君は忠香の養女となり、「省君」と改名。
sen.e: Nobukimi was adopted by Tadaka and changed her name to "Shokimi".
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Nobukimi was adopted by Tadaka and changed her name to "Shokimi".
Nobukimi was adopted by Tadaka and changed her name to "Shokimi".

sen.j: 嘉永6年（1853年）5月18日（旧暦）に婚約が調い、江戸に下向。
sen.e: After the engagement was fixed on May 18, 1853, she went down to Edo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: After the engagement was fixed on June 24, 1853, she went down to Edo.
sen.cmt: 旧暦の日付表示を新暦に変換しました。
sen.e: After the engagement was fixed on June 24, 1853, she went down to Edo.

sen.j: 安政2年（1855年）11月15日に結納、同年12月3日に結婚した。
sen.e: The engagement ceremony was held on November 15, 1855 and then she got married on December 3 of the same year.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The engagement ceremony was held on December 23, 1855 and then she got married on January 10, 1856.
sen.cmt: 旧暦の日付表示を新暦に変換しました。
sen.e: The engagement ceremony was held on December 23, 1855 and then she got married on January 10, 1856.

sen.j: 慶喜との間に安政5年（1858年）7月16日に女子を出産するも、20日には夭折。
sen.e: She gave birth to a daughter of Yoshinobu on July 16, 1858 but the daughter died young on July 20.
She gave birth to a daughter of Yoshinobu on August 24, 1858 but the daughter died young on August 28.
sen.cmt: 旧暦の日付表示を新暦に変換しました。
sen.e: She gave birth to a daughter of Yoshinobu on August 24, 1858 but the daughter died young on August 28.

sen.j: 更に、その後夫が将軍後見職となり、将軍徳川家茂と共に京都に向かい、長い別居生活にはいる。
sen.e: After that, she started living apart from her husband because he became Shogun-kokenshoku (one of three major posts of Edo bakufu) and accompanied Shogun Iemochi TOKUGAWA to Kyoto.
After that, she started living apart from her husband because he became Shogun-kokenshoku (one of three major posts of Edo bakufu) and accompanied Shogun Iemochi TOKUGAWA to Kyoto.
After that, she started living apart from her husband because he became Shogun-kokenshoku (one of three major posts of Edo bakufu) and accompanied Shogun Iemochi TOKUGAWA to Kyoto.

sen.j: 慶応2年（1866年）に慶喜は将軍となるが、この時も慶喜は入洛中であり、省子も江戸城大奥には入っていない。
sen.e: Yoshinobu became Shogun in 1866, but he was still in Kyoto and Shoko did not enter the inner palace of the Edo Castle at that time.
Yoshinobu became Shogun in 1866, but he was still in Kyoto and Shoko did not enter the inner palace of the Edo Castle at that time.
Yoshinobu became Shogun in 1866, but he was still in Kyoto and Shoko did not enter the inner palace of the Edo Castle at that time.

sen.j: 慶応4年（1868年）1月にようやく慶喜は江戸に戻ってくるが、それは将軍職を返上した後のことであった。
sen.e: Yoshinobu was back to Edo in January, 1868 at last after he returned the shogunate.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Yoshinobu was back to Edo around January or February 1868 at last after he gave up the shogunate.
sen.cmt: 旧暦の日付表示を新暦に変換しました。
sen.e: Yoshinobu was back to Edo around January or February 1868 at last after he gave up the shogunate.

sen.j: 更に慶喜はそのまま上野寛永寺、引き続き駿府宝台院にて謹慎生活に入り、省子は対面することが出来なかった。
sen.e: Shoko could not see him because Yoshinobu was confined to the Ueno Kanei-ji Temple followed by the Sunpu Hodai-in Temple soon after his return.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Shoko could not see him because Yoshinobu was confined to the Ueno Kanei-ji Temple, and then to the Sunpu Hodai-in Temple, soon after his return.
sen.cmt: 「駿府宝台院にて謹慎する」という流れであることを明確にするためtoを補います。
sen.e: Shoko could not see him because Yoshinobu was confined to the Ueno Kanei-ji Temple, and then to the Sunpu Hodai-in Temple, soon after his return.

sen.j: 明治維新後も慶喜は静岡市、省子は東京の一橋屋敷という別居生活は続いた。
sen.e: Even after the Meiji Restoration, the separation continued - Yoshinbu lived in Shizuoka while Shoko lived in the Hitotsubashi residence.
Even after the Meiji Restoration, the separation continued - Yoshinbu lived in Shizuoka while Shoko lived in the Hitotsubashi residence in Tokyo.
Even after the Meiji Restoration, the separation continued - Yoshinbu lived in Shizuoka while Shoko lived in the Hitotsubashi residence in Tokyo.

sen.j: この頃、「省子」から「美賀子」に改名。
sen.e: Around that time, she changed her name from "Shoko" to "Mikako".
Around that time, she changed her name from "Shoko" to "Mikako".
Around that time, she changed her name from 'Shoko' to 'Mikako'.
sen.cmt: ダブルクォーテーションをシングルクォーテーションにしました。

sen.j: 明治2年（1869年）9月に慶喜の謹慎が解除され、その2ヶ月後に美賀子は静岡に向かい、10年ぶりに共に暮らすようになる。
sen.e: Mikako left for Shizuoka two months after Yoshinobu was released from the confinement in September, 1869, and then lived together for the first time in ten years.
Mikako left for Shizuoka two months after Yoshinobu was released from the confinement in September, 1869, and then lived together for the first time in ten years.
Mikako left for Shizuoka two months after Yoshinobu was released from the confinement in September, 1869, and then lived together for the first time in ten years.

sen.j: その後、慶喜は新村信、中根幸という側室を抱えたが、その間に生まれた子供はすべて美賀子を実母として育てられた。
sen.e: Then, Yoshinobu had concubines named Nobu SHINMURA and Sachi NAKANE, but all the children of the concubines and Yoshinobu were raised as Mikako's children.
After that Yoshinobu had concubines named Nobu SHINMURA and Sachi NAKANE, but all of Yoshinobu's children born of those concubines were raised as Mikako's children.
sen.cmt: 「その間に生まれた子供」を分かりやすく言い換えます。
sen.e: After that Yoshinobu had concubines named Nobu SHINMURA and Sachi NAKANE, but all of Yoshinobu's children born of those concubines were raised as Mikako's children.

sen.j: 明治27年（1894年）、乳癌を発症。
sen.e: She developed breast cancer in 1894.
She developed breast cancer in 1894.
She developed breast cancer in 1894.

sen.j: 術後の容態は思わしくなく、5月に治療のため東京の徳川家達の屋敷に移るが、回復せず7月9日死去。
sen.e: She moved to the residence of the Tokugawa families in Tokyo for medication in May because conditions after surgery were not good, but she died without recovery on July 9.
She moved to the residence of the Tokugawa families in Tokyo for medication in May because conditions after surgery were not good, but she died without recovery on July 9.
She moved to the residence of the Tokugawa families in Tokyo for medication in May because conditions after surgery were not good, but she died without recovery on July 9.

sen.j: 享年60。
sen.e: She was 60 years old.
She was 60 years old then.
sen.cmt: 「死亡時の年齢」であることを明確にするためthenを補います。
sen.e: She was 60 years old then.

sen.j: 院号は「貞粛院」、墓所は東京の谷中墓地。
sen.e: Her ingo (a posthumous title given to a Buddhist) is "Teishukuin" and her grave is in Yanaka Cemetery.
Her ingo (a posthumous title given to a Buddhist) is "Teishukuin" and her grave is in Yanaka Cemetery.
Her ingo (a posthumous title given to a Buddhist) is 'Teishukuin' and her grave is in Yanaka Cemetery.
sen.cmt: ダブルクォーテーションをシングルクォーテーションにしました。

sen.j: 静岡で見送った慶喜に送った和歌（美賀子の辞世の句として紹介されることが多い）。
sen.e: The waka (a traditional Japanese poem of thirty-one syllables) sent to Yoshinobu who saw her off in Shizuoka (often introduced as Mikako's farewell poem composed on the eve of her death) says:
The waka (a traditional Japanese poem of thirty-one syllables) sent to Yoshinobu who saw her off in Shizuoka (often introduced as Mikako's farewell poem composed on the eve of her death) says:
The waka (a traditional Japanese poem of thirty-one syllables) sent to Yoshinobu who saw her off in Shizuoka (often introduced as Mikako's farewell poem composed on the eve of her death) says:

sen.j: 「かくはかり うたて別をするか路に つきぬ名残は ふちのしらゆき」
sen.e: "I have to say farewell to you who are on the street in such a way, the sorrow of parting does not disappear like snow on the mountain top."
sen.cmt: 意味解釈が困難なため直訳になりました。
sen.e: "I have to say farewell to you who are on the street in such a way, the sorrow of parting does not disappear like snow on the mountain top."
I have to say farewell to you who are on the street in such a way, the sorrow of parting does not disappear like snow on the mountain top.'
sen.cmt: ダブルクォーテーションをシングルクォーテーションにしました。

sen.j: 人物
sen.e: Personal Profile
Personal Profile
Personal Profile

sen.j: 慶喜との婚約自体が、代役として急遽決められた物であった上、慶喜は徳川慶壽未亡人・東明宮直子（とめのみやつねこ）女王と大変に仲が良かったため、美賀子は非常に寂しい新婚生活を送ったと言われる。
sen.e: It is said that she had lonely newly-married life because Yoshinobu was intimate with Tsuneko TOMENOMIYA, a widow of Yoshihisa TOKUGAWA in addition to the fact that her engagement to Yoshinobu was determined as a replacement on very short notice.

It is said that she had a very lonely newly-married life because Yoshinobu was very intimate with Tsuneko TOMENOMIYA, a widow of Yoshihisa TOKUGAWA, and also because her engagement to Yoshinobu had been determined as a replacement on very short notice.
sen.cmt: 「大変に」「非常に」の訳漏れを修正しました。In addition to the fact～では《理由》であることが分かりにくいためbecause節に変更しました。
sen.e: It is said that she had a very lonely newly-married life because Yoshinobu was very intimate with Tsuneko TOMENOMIYA, a widow of Yoshihisa TOKUGAWA, and also because her engagement to Yoshinobu had been determined as a replacement on very short notice.

sen.j: 更に、結婚後3年経ってようやく授かった女子もすぐに死んだことから、ますます性格はふさぎ込むようになっていったと言われる。
sen.e: Furthermore, her daughter she had three years after the marriage died soon and therefore it is said that she got more depressed.
Furthermore, the tragically early death of her daughter, whom she finally had three years after the marriage, made her more depressed.
sen.cmt: 分かりやすくなるよう文構造を修正しました。
sen.e: Furthermore, the tragically early death of her daughter, whom she finally had three years after the marriage, made her more depressed.

sen.j: 慶喜の謹慎解除後になって、ようやく慶喜生母・吉子女王、直子の取りなしにより静岡に向かい同居した。
sen.e: Finally after Yoshinobu was released from the confinement, she went to Shizuoka and lived together through the mediation of Yoshinobu's mother, Princess Tomi no miya Yoshiko.
Finally, after Yoshinobu was released from the confinement, she went to Shizuoka and lived together with him through the mediation of Yoshinobu's mother, Princess Tomi no miya Yoshiko.
sen.cmt: 「誰と」同居するのかを明示すべきです。
sen.e: Finally, after Yoshinobu was released from the confinement, she went to Shizuoka and lived together with him through the mediation of Yoshinobu's mother, Princess Tomi no miya Yoshiko.

sen.j: その後はそれなりに夫婦仲も修復したようである。
sen.e: After that, the marriage seemed to relatively get well.
After that, the marriage seemed to get relatively well.
sen.cmt: このrelativelyは副詞wellを修飾すると解すべきです。
sen.e: After that, the marriage seemed to get relatively well.

sen.j: 但し、美賀子は病弱であった事もあって、二度と子供を授かることは無かった。
sen.e: However, Mikako never had a child because she had poor health.
However, Mikako never had a child because she had poor health.
However, Mikako never had a child because she had poor health.

sen.j: 因みに美賀子との仲はしっくりいかなかった慶喜であるが、美賀子の実家との仲は良好で、将軍後見職を務めていた頃には菊亭（今出川）家の世話になっている。
sen.e: In fact, Yoshonobu did not have a good relation with Mikako, but he got along with her parents and relied on the Kikutei (Imadegawa) family when he was the Shogun-kokenshoku.
In fact, Yoshonobu did not have a good relation with Mikako, but he got along with her parents and relied on the Kikutei (Imadegawa) family when he was the Shogun-kokenshoku.
In fact, Yoshonobu did not have a good relation with Mikako, but he got along with her parents and relied on the Kikutei (Imadegawa) family when he was the Shogun-kokenshoku.

sen.j: 慶喜は将軍在職時に江戸城に入城しなかった事もあって、美賀子も将軍正室でありながら一度も江戸城へ入城することは無かった。
sen.e: Although Mikako was the Shogun's lawful wife, she never entered the Edo Castle because Yoshinobu didn't when he was Shogun.
Although Mikako was the Shogun's lawful wife, she never entered the Edo Castle because Yoshinobu didn't when he was Shogun.
Although Mikako was the Shogun's lawful wife, she never entered the Edo Castle because Yoshinobu didn't when he was Shogun.
